title: Coca-Cola Sales Up 10% as Demand Holds Amid Rising Prices; Beverage company raises revenue guidance for year as third-quarter earnings top Wall Street views
text:
The Atlanta-based company attributed the rise to factors including a 12% jump in price mix, calculated based on changes in operating revenue from its mix of products and the geographic regions those sales occurred.

The company's global case volume increased 4% year over year, driven by strong international sales. Away-from-home markets leading that growth included Western Europe and Mexico, the company said.

Sales for sparkling soft drinks rose 3% globally, while sales for nutrition, juice, dairy and plant-based beverages were flat. Sales for hydration, sports, coffee and tea drinks grew 5%.

Overall for the quarter, Coca-Cola posted a net income of $2.8 billion, or 65 cents a share, compared with $2.5 billion, or 57 cents a share, a year earlier.

Stripping out one-time items, Coca-Cola said adjusted earnings were 69 cents a share. Analysts polled by FactSet had been forecasting adjusted earnings of 64 cents a share.

Revenue came in at $11.1 billion, ahead of analyst estimates of $10.5 billion.

Earlier this month, rival PepsiCo Inc. reported a nearly 9% rise in third-quarter revenue after rising prices offset higher input and operating costs.

In premarket trading, Coca-Cola shares were up 2%.

Write to Sabela Ojea at sabela.ojea@wsj.com

Coca-Cola Sales Up 10% as Demand Holds Amid Rising Prices
